title: how much does swelling really go down?
post:
i’m currently a little over 3 weeks post op and have been healing very well! got a bit of T-junction breakdown which is annoying but my surgeon isn’t worried so i feel pretty good. 

the only thing is, i feel like my breasts haven’t really gone down in size from day 1 of post op? i know that i can’t really know my size accurately at least until a couple months after surgery, but also shouldn’t i notice some decrease in swelling by now?

like everyone else i’m worried i’ll end up bigger than anticipated and want to know if i should prepare myself for only minor changes in my size going forward. 

tl;dr was the change from early recovery to a couple months post op noticeable/significant? what was your experience with swelling after reduction like?
disclosure: a little over 3 weeks post op
label: Health

comment: My experience (it seems like many people's experience on here) was that swelling was at its peak around week 3.  We're all different, but know that you might be in the height of your swelling.
label: Health

title: depression or just istp?
post: I was clinically depressed during the COVID lockdown so I know what full-on depression is like for me.. not eating, constantly sleeping/laying around, always distracting myself through social media or music, etc. But I’ve recovered since then and have been off my meds for over a year now. Ever since I’ve been ok, but I’m never that happy. It just feels like I’m floating through life, like if the day was ok then I’m ok, there’s not much depth to it. I know we are pretty emotionless so maybe it’s normal idk. But I also realized I’m not as emotionally tied to anything like most people.. jobs, partners, homes. It just all feels temporary and i have a “it will do for now” or “it is what it is” mentality (But I think this view is valid because life is just constant change and impermanence). For example, my coworkers always complain about our job but for me it’s okay, I know I just need money and don’t plan on staying for long. That said; they have been working there for 6+ years while it’s been 9 months for me. I have dreams like my own business and modeling, moving to the city, etc that I can’t carry out yet bc I’m still in college. But they give me enough to want to keep going and life feels ok for the most part. But nights like this I lay awake and just realize I feel kind of empty. It doesn’t really bother me but sometimes I think it’s too much emptiness if that makes sense. I look at other people and their enthusiasm for life seems a whole other level compared to mine. Whereas I kind of live day to day, and feel meh about everything.
label: Mental_Health

title: Sex Education Survey (Repost)
post: Hello, my name is Rachael and I am a doctoral student in clinical psychology at the University of Indianapolis. I am conducting a research study on sexual education and well-being and would like you to consider participating. Participation in the study means a brief (\~10 minute) research survey about sexual education and sexual well-being. This study will help build insight into sex education programming and how it impacts individuals in early adulthood. If you agree to participate, you must be a U.S. Citizen, between age 18 and 30, and currently enrolled in college or university. Participants must also be neurodivergent (have a diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder, Autism, or Asperger’s Syndrome). To participate, click [here](https://uindy.co1.qualtrics.com/jfe/form/SV_0J05E476iV0OU1E).
label: Name

title: Describe your experience presenting for the first time
post:
So I just presented fully fem for the first time, wearing a straight up dress, bra, tights and boots. You could call the dress a really long jumper if pressed, but basically a dress, and I had pretty visible boobs while sat down. 

However, while I was nervous leaving the house, and happy when I got back to reflect on it, the experience itself was just kinda fine, maybe even just mid. Went to the local mall, browsed the shops, had lunch at Costa. It just felt very normal. I think I was happy, and it was a pleasant experience, but in a really subtle way. I guess my feelings weren't as strong as I expected. 

Now I'm curious what other people's experiences were like in comparison, presenting differently for the first time. Did you feel extremely happy, more nervous, did it differ from what you expected? I'd appreciate some insight into how you felt and if the feelings differ from person to person.
disclosure: I just presented fully fem for the first time, wearing a straight up dress, bra, tights and boots.
label: Appearance

title: Describe your experience presenting for the first time
post:
So I just presented fully fem for the first time, wearing a straight up dress, bra, tights and boots. You could call the dress a really long jumper if pressed, but basically a dress, and I had pretty visible boobs while sat down. 

However, while I was nervous leaving the house, and happy when I got back to reflect on it, the experience itself was just kinda fine, maybe even just mid. Went to the local mall, browsed the shops, had lunch at Costa. It just felt very normal. I think I was happy, and it was a pleasant experience, but in a really subtle way. I guess my feelings weren't as strong as I expected. 

Now I'm curious what other people's experiences were like in comparison, presenting differently for the first time. Did you feel extremely happy, more nervous, did it differ from what you expected? I'd appreciate some insight into how you felt and if the feelings differ from person to person.
parent_comment: My first time out of the house was a Halloween party. I got so many compliments on my costume I ended up coming out to everyone that night. I’ll never forget how nice it felt having a dress swoosh around while I walked. It was euphoric.
comment:
That's awesome. I love costumes, so I hope I have an experience like that someday. I just went out locally on my own, so maybe doing it with friends (if I had any) would feel better. I've cosplayed a female character at a comic con before - I don't really consider it as my first time presenting, since you get lots of crossdressers at these cons - but I didn't get a ton of compliments, though the few I did get did make me happy.

I'm almost 23, so still quite young, but can't help but feel I missed out on so much youth, going to parties and wearing sexy dresses, not realising why I always isolated myself and hated hanging with other people until now. I'm still very much an introvert, but it's easier to imagine interacting with others as a woman than anything else.

Next con, I'm going as a goth maid character with a longer dress, so maybe that'll be a cooler experience. Out of curiosity, what was your costume at this party?
label: Age

title: Describe your experience presenting for the first time
post:
So I just presented fully fem for the first time, wearing a straight up dress, bra, tights and boots. You could call the dress a really long jumper if pressed, but basically a dress, and I had pretty visible boobs while sat down. 

However, while I was nervous leaving the house, and happy when I got back to reflect on it, the experience itself was just kinda fine, maybe even just mid. Went to the local mall, browsed the shops, had lunch at Costa. It just felt very normal. I think I was happy, and it was a pleasant experience, but in a really subtle way. I guess my feelings weren't as strong as I expected. 

Now I'm curious what other people's experiences were like in comparison, presenting differently for the first time. Did you feel extremely happy, more nervous, did it differ from what you expected? I'd appreciate some insight into how you felt and if the feelings differ from person to person.
parent_comment: Mine was at a drag show at uni, and I won the amateur contest lol. My friends let me borrow their clothes, but I also bought a cheap decent dress. I wasn't even an egg yet but now here I am
comment:
Sounds cool. Reminds me when I went on a pub crawl in my first year of uni, as I didn't become an egg until my third year. I took the 80s costume theme in a weird direction, and wore a skeleton morphsuit with neon legwarmers and tights (while everyone else was a ghostbuster or ninja turtle; I don't know what my brain was on). 

It wasn't super feminine looking I don't think, but pretty flamboyant. However, I don't drink and my social skills are severely lacking, so it was a pretty lackluster night for me, but weirdly enough, I didn't feel as nervous going out like that than I expected. Guess I know why now.

Still, a drag show would have been great. Must have felt awesome to embrace femininity and flamboyance like that.
disclosure: wore a skeleton morphsuit with neon legwarmers
label: Appearance

comment:
I was pre-everything (including realising I'm a woman. My intention was just to pick up cross-dressing as a hobby and a power trip ("can other men do *this*?")). Facial hair shadow, hairy legs, short hair, the works.

It was absolutely terrifying, but in reality, nobody gave a shit. I love Australia.
disclosure: My intention was just to pick up cross-dressing as a hobby

comment:
I simply wore skinny jeans, a hoodie, breastforms stuffed into a sports bra, and a bit of foundation. And tbh I probably did not even need the foundation at all—a lot of it got wiped off around my mouth anyways because I was wearing a mask most of the time while I was indoors.

Surprisingly, too, everyone assumed I was a woman. Can’t say I was too unhappy about that! By then, though, I’d already mastered my new voice and had been dressing feminine around the apartment so I also had tucking mastered as well.
disclosure: I simply wore skinny jeans, a hoodie, breastforms stuffed into a sports bra, and a bit of foundation
label: Appearance

title: Suing my former employer Softsages Technologies.
post:
Currently in the process of suing my former employer [SoftSages Technology](https://www.linkedin.com/company/softsages-technology/)   as it took them nearly 2 weeks after my final termination a few months   ago to service my final paycheck and failed to pay the 3 week  severance  promised at document signing. Then flat lied to DoL saying  that I was a  contractor even though I signed a w2 and they withheld  taxes from my  paychecks. Luckily I still have a copy of every email and  form ever sent/signed.

Fair warning to anyone who intends to work at [SoftSages Technology](https://www.linkedin.com/company/softsages-technology/)  


Position lasted all of a week after I moved across state to get to it.
label: Occupation

title: Advice needed
post:
I have a technical college degree and my full time job is in IT management. I have been in IT for over 20 yrs. 

My sales experience comes from being a realtor (part time) also for over 20 yrs. 

Due to some big medical issues, I can no longer do real estate. I am hoping to find something I can do from home.  Remote zoom calls and/or phone calls. 

I have kids in college and lots of medical bills ; what my health insurance didn’t pay and possibly more health expenses in a few months 

Can you PLEASE provide some advice as to what type of PART TIME (2-3 hrs/day and weekends) sales I should get into?

I don’t mind if it is 100% commission as long as it is worth my effort/time

Thank you in advance
disclosure: I have a technical college degree
label: Education

title: Does POC suffice for MD order?
post: I off-ramped for too long from the profession and missed the part about Direct Access.  Just learning about it now at my new HH (Med B) job.  In searching this out, I learned that my state (NY) is DA but requires MD order at 30 days / 10 visits.  So in not trusting the company I work for, I'd like legit ethical answers from my PT community here as to what that really means at 30 days/10 visits?  Does the POC signed by a MD suffice for this state requirement?  Does Medicare also accept this?
label: Occupation

title: Just looking for reassurance
post:
My throat has been bothering me particularly these last couple of days. Right now it feels dry despite staying well-hydrated. Since my endoscopy revealed Barrett’s in August, I’ve been much better about managing the throat-related anxiety, but tonight it’s hard.

Someone remind me that if I can swallow, breathe, and talk, then I’m fine, because my brain doesn’t believe me. 😂😭
label: Health
